Award.AwardTitle: Relative velocity changes using ambient seismic noise at Okmok and Redoubt volcanoes, Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs will improve the ability to detect precursory activity leading to active
volcanism at both Okmok caldera and Redoubt volcano, Alaska, as well as increase understanding of
the complexity of magma storage at Redoubt. They will investigate important questions at Redoubt
regarding (1) the spatial extent of the magma chamber, (2) if magma migrates from a primary magma
chamber to a second magma reservoir located somewhere between 2 and 4.5 km depth, (3) if temporary
perturbations to the upper crustal velocity structure of Redoubt, reflecting CO2 degassed at mid-crustal
depths, can be observed, possibly as early as several months prior to the 2009 event, thus serving as an
early indicator of the eruption. At Okmok, they will examine important questions including (1) the
existence of early signs of volcanic unrest preceding the 2008 eruption and/or (2) early indicators that the
eruption would emanate NW of Cone D instead of an expected eruption at Cone A, (3) if there were
indications of shallow magma movement (1-3 km depth) within the caldera in the months leading up to
the 2008 eruption. One promising approach to improve detection of precursory activity leading to active
volcanism at Okmok and Redoubt is to carry out seismic interferometry using ambient noise recorded at
these volcanoes (specifically pre- through post-eruption for the 2008 Okmok and 2009 Redoubt
eruptions).

Okmok and Redoubt are two of the most active volcanoes in the Aleutian Arc and, as
such, pose major hazards to people living within these regions, air traffic, local fisheries, and local oil
production facilities. This study will improve our ability to detect precursory activity leading to active
volcanism at both Okmok and Redoubt as well as increase our understanding of the complexity of magma
storage at Redoubt. The proposed study will also broaden the experience of an early career female
scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Okmok is one of the most active volcanoes in the Aleutian Arc. It is 30 km wide and hosts a 10 km wide caldera (crater formed during past major eruptions). Leading into its most recent eruption in 2008, the volcano showed precursors to volcanic activity only several hours before it erupted explosively. Frequent, and at times unpredictable, volcanic activity at Okmok poses a major hazard due to the heavily trafficked north Pacific air routes that overly it. Additionally, the volcano is adjacent to several of the world’s most productive fisheries. For these reasons, it is imperative that we improve our ability to detect precursory activity leading to eruption at Okmok. 

In an effort to improve our ability to detect precursory volcanic activity at the volcano, we studied Okmok during a period of time when it was rapidly inflating. A technique called ambient noise interferometry was applied during this time period in order to determine changes in seismic velocity occurring at the volcano. Seismic velocity is the velocity at which seismic waves can propagate through the subsurface. Regions outside the volcano showed changes in seismic velocity that were related to seasonal changes in the hydrologic cycle (seasonal snow pack, snow melt, rain, etc.). Within Okmok’s caldera, we observed large decreases in seismic velocity coincident in time with rapid inflation of the volcano. The magnitude of these relative velocity decreases are comparable to previous studies that applied the ambient noise interferometry technique at Piton de la Fournaise volcano. These previous studies associate such large decreases in seismic velocity with the migration of gas and/or magma to shallower depths within the volcano. Notably, the magnitude and distribution of decreases in seismic velocity we determined within Okmok’s caldera suggest that the source of inflation is located approximately within the center of the caldera and represents recharge of shallow magma storage in this location. Importantly, there is a relative absence of earthquakes associated with this and previous time periods of rapid inflation of Okmok volcano. Thus, these results are the first seismic evidence of such rapid inflation at the volcano.
